speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 14-86, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission v. Abercrombie & Fitch Stores. Mr. Gershengorn.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand.  What is the difference between knowing and correctly understanding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Does that subjective -- I'm sorry.  Does that subjective or -- is it even relevant?  Meaning -- the issue is whether they failed to hire her because of her religious practice.  Whether the person thinks it is is the issue.  I mean, that's why they acted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But getting back to Justice Scalia's question, I think there's some substantial force to your argument that the employee doesn't have to mention this first. But why -- why do we -- import the term understand instead of know.  In a treatment case, the whole idea is that -- that prohibited action was taken because of religion.  It's what you knew.  Why -- why are you making it so confusing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your position -- your statement that you opened with is -- is that he must understand.  You stay away from the word "know".  And Justice Scalia asked you what -- why you did that, and I can't understand your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Gershengorn, I mean, so that does raise the question if yours is less than certainty, how much less than certainty is it?  I mean, suppose I'm an employer, and I say, you know, I don't honestly know, I think.  You know, it's two out of three.  Is that sufficient?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Is that true even if it's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No.  You're promoting -- Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Is that true even if it's under 50 percent?  In other words, say that employer says, you know, I really don't know, but I think there's, like, a 50/50 chance or even a 40 percent chance that this person has a religious -- that -- has religious -- that this practice is religious.  And I don't really feel like getting into all this accommodation stuff, so I'm not going to hire this person.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So it doesn't really depend on what the percentage chance is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It could be certain, it could be less than certain, it could be a lot less than certain, as long as the employer says there's some chance, and I'm not going to hire, or promote, or fire, Alderson Reporting Company or whatever, because of that chance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not sure I understand why you're fighting Justice Kagan's question. Isn't the issue the reason that they acted? They refused to hire someone because they had a 1 percent belief that they had a religious -- pardon the pun -- a religious belief that they wouldn't Alderson Reporting Company accommodate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: confusing me enormously.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: To understand --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't care --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- what they've used.  That doesn't make any sense to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Gershengorn, didn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- she -- the person -- the first-line hire, person responsible for hiring, didn't she say to the district manager, I think she's wearing this headscarf for religious reasons, and that's why I'm checking it out with you.  The answer she got Alderson Reporting Company back was, it doesn't matter whether it's for religious reasons.  We don't -- we don't accommodate people who wear headscarfs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So -- so it seems that the -- the district manager is -- his point of view is headscarfs are out.  This particular woman was wearing one for religious reasons, but it doesn't matter what reason, we don't accommodate headscarfs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, it didn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There is no law against such a rule.  Any employer can have a rule, We don't allow headscarfs.  And until someone applies for a job who, for a religious reason, wants to wear a headscarf and the employer knows that it's for a religious reason or suspects, or believes, or understands, or whatever verbs you want to use, there's been no violation of the law.  You can -- you can have that rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We don't allow our Alderson Reporting Company employees to wear headscarfs.  Nothing wrong with that rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the mere fact that this -- this supervisor said that doesn't prove a violation by the employer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right, but that supervisor did not have that knowledge.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, your -- your solution that you suggested is that if there's some doubt the employer should begin a dialogue, I think is what you -- but I think that may promote stereotypes to a far greater degree than what you're objecting to. Let's say you have someone of Middle Eastern appearance who shows up for the interview with a beard. And the employer, like Abercrombie & Fitch, they don't like beards.  They don't want their models, as they call them, having beards.  But he doesn't know if the beard is there for a  religious reason or not. So you think it's better to him to sit there and start asking this applicant questions he would not ask anyone else about religion?  Why are you wearing a beard?  Is there some religious reason for that?  It seems that your solution causes more problems.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, is it reasonable for an employer to say, look, I don't want to buy into some problem with a guy who has a beard.  I'm going to say can you shave it?  He's going to say no or he's only going to shave twice a week. I mean, isn't he reasonably going to say -- let's say, I don't care if it's religious -- a religious reason or not.  The guy shows up with a beard.  I'm not going to hire him. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You could avoid those hard questions, whether it's understand, believe, suspect, by adopting the rule that the court of appeals adopted here; and that is, if you want to sue me for denying you a job for a religious reason, the burden is on you to say, I'm wearing the headscarf for a religious reason, or I'm wearing the beard for a religious reason. That -- that avoids all problems.  Once you notify the employer that it's for a religious reason, you got 'em. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the employer tell her -- did the employer tell her that it had this Look Policy --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that a headscarf would violate?  How could she ask for something when she didn't know the employer had such a rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, wait a minute.  This is not the place to get into the facts.  But I -- I thought her friend told her to wear at least a colored scarf, so the subject came up.  So I -- I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Again, we're -- we're not Alderson Reporting Company factfinders here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To get --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To get back to my beard case, is there -- if it's someone with a Middle Alderson Reporting Company Eastern appearance with a beard, you want the employer to begin some kind of a dialogue.  If it's somebody who's not Middle Eastern and has a beard, can the employer assume, well, I don't think that's for religious reasons? In other words, he's going to be asking religious questions of some people based on a stereotype, but not others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why -- why does he have to ask about religious beliefs?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could you answer my question, please?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why can't the employer just simply say, we have a Look Policy that doesn't permit beards.  Can you comply with that policy? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's all they have to -- they don't have to ask about reasons or no reasons.  It doesn't really matter why.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The question is supposed -- the question is supposed to be why are you wearing a beard?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So that doesn't cover anything that's not immediately apparent -- apparent by the appearance.  You make -- they can have a code of conduct that presumably would go through several pages, here are all the things we require.  Any problem with any of them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could -- could I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand.  Could -- could I ask you -- he can ask can you do it?  Is -- is that the only religious preference that has to be honored?  I can, but, you know, really, I would like not to for a religious reason.  I -- I guess I could take off my headscarf or whatnot, but it would be very inappropriate, religiously uncomfortable. Is -- is that a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are -- are you acknowledging that -- that the only accommodation that has to be made is an accommodation for somebody who absolutely for a religious reason cannot do something?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't think so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you can't ask that. You -- you cannot ask the question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- you're telling them to ask, can you do it?  Well, yes, I guess I could, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So she says, yes, I could. And later says, yeah, I could, but -- but, boy, it is really uncomfortable for me to do that for religious reasons.  Would she still have a lawsuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All she said was, yes, I could.  She could.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, couldn't the employer say, we have a policy no beards, or whatever, do you have any problem with that?  Why do you have to -- why Alderson Reporting Company does it have to be phrased, could you do it?  Just say, do you have any problem with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Are you willing to do it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The Respondent says that you switched theories in midstream, that you started out with a refusal to accommodate theory and then you Alderson Reporting Company abandoned that.  Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- not so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So that -- that's disparate treatment plus failure to accommodate, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  Again, I'm a little confused.  I didn't know -- I -- I read your complaint, and it says, "The Respondent refused to hire Ms. Elauf because she wears a hijab and further failed to accommodate her religious belief by making an exception to the Look Policy." I looked at your briefs, I looked at the jury charge; and it seems like the two were always tied. The failure to hire was because they refused to accommodate her.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, suppose they had. Their argument is that you get damages only for Alderson Reporting Company intentional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm sorry to be obtuse.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't know why you just don't concede that that's a form of disparate -- Alderson Reporting Company disparate treatment.  Failure to accommodate is a form of disparate treatment.  I don't accommodate you because of your religion.  Disparate treatment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You know what?  I -- I'm -- I'm just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- missing something.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Dvoretzky.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: They don't have to offer a religious accommodation if they have a reasonable basis not to.  I mean, you follow the statute.  You only have to accommodate if it's not an undue burden.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No.  It's not an un- -- we go back to their position. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's very simple, because you're mischaracterizing it.  Their position is, if you believe that someone -- believe, know -- we're -- a lot of adjectives -- that someone will need a religious accommodation, then -- and won't comply with your policy, just ask them, do you have a -- just the way Justice Alito said.  You know, we don't permit facial hair on the floor.  You have a problem with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do you think that the -- do you think that the employee has to say, I am dressed the way I am for a religious reason?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right.  Let's say four -- four people show up for a job interview at Abercrombie. And half -- this is going to sound like a joke, but, you know, it's not. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So the first is a Sikh man wearing a turban, the second is a Hasidic man wearing a hat, the third is a Muslim woman wearing a niqab, the fourth is a Catholic nun in a habit. Now, do you think the employer has to -- that those people have to say, we just want to tell you, we're dressed this way for a religious reason.  We're not just trying to make a fashion statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are the what?  Group?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, that can be the case, but I want to know the answer to the question whether the employee has to say, I'm wearing this for a religious reason, or whether you're willing to admit that there are at least some circumstances in which the employer is charged with that knowledge based on what the employer observes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Actually, I didn't think that was the question.  I thought the question presented was that the Tenth Circuit had said, Employer, unless you know from the woman who is applying, from the applicant, unless you receive direct, explicit notice that what she wants to wear is based on religion and she wants an accommodation, unless you receive direct, explicit notice from her, you're home free to do what you want. Now, in their question presented, they say, in the last few words in describing it, we think that's wrong. Now, I agree that we have to say whether that's wrong and, if it is wrong, it would be helpful to say what they have to do.  So the SG says, here is what it is.  If the employer correctly infers, correctly understands, and I would add "or correctly believes" that a practice is religious and an accommodation is necessary, that's it.  Then he has to accommodate unless he has one of the excuses under the statute, et cetera. Okay.        What's wrong with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is -- it is unadministrable to say that if the employer believes, thinks, this woman is religious and needs an accommodation and he's right, well, do something unless you have an excuse. What -- why is that unadministrable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh no, you have to prove. This -- this is correct.  You have to prove he has a belief.  Now, we probably in 250,000 Federal cases a year, of those, say, 80,000 that go to trial.  Proving that somebody has a belief or other is probably at issue in 90 percent of them.  Now, I'm making that up, that number, but nonetheless, I don't think it's uncommon in the law that you have to prove that somebody believes something.  So we say, the standard of proving belief is like in any other case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: This is -- this is such --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Now, Mr. Dvoretzky, suppose an employer just doesn't want to hire any Jews, and somebody walks in and his name is Noah Goldberg, and he looks kind of Jewish and the employer doesn't know he's Jewish.  No absolute certainty and certainly Mr. Goldberg doesn't say anything about being Jewish, but the employer just operates on an assumption that he's Jewish, so no, he doesn't get the job.  Is that a violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That has got to be against the law, right?  It doesn't matter whether the employer -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It doesn't matter whether the employer knows it to an absolute certainty, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Except in Title VII, you would be right if all that Title VII did was prevent religious discrimination, but it makes a religious practice, a refusal to accommodate a religious practice is itself a violation of Title VII. So we have -- it's -- and that was done deliberately, was it not, so that religious practices would have to be accommodated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But the thing about my question was, is that what this statute does is to say that if you are, in fact, wearing a headscarf for religious reasons, that your neutral policy really doesn't matter, it only matters if you -- if there's an Alderson Reporting Company undue burden and you really can't make an accommodation, but except for that, it really doesn't matter.  You just have to hire me, even if I'm wearing a headscarf.  And so the fact that you don't know that I'm wearing a headscarf for religious reasons, that you only kind of assume that, because most people do wear headscarves for religious reasons, it shouldn't make any more difference than in the hypothetical that I gave.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's if the employee knows the rule.  But here the employee had no reason to think that there was anything offensive about her dress. How can she say, by the way, I have a religious reason for wearing this headscarf, when from everything, from Alderson Reporting Company all appearances, the employer doesn't care.  It's okay to wear a headscarf.  Then the employer has not given her notice of this Look Policy, so how is she supposed to in -- in -- intrude the question, that as far as all appearances go, it's fine, that she's wearing a headscarf.  There's no Look Policy that the employee knows that's violated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did she testify that she knew they had a dress code?  I was not aware of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But she did.  In fact, she came in with an Abercrombie type shirt, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But she asked a friend, who worked for Abercrombie whether the -- whether the Alderson Reporting Company headscarf was a problem, and the friend said, no, if it's not black, it should be okay.  And in fact, three of the four managers said it was okay to wear scarves, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- why would she suspect that if she is qualified and has the personality they're looking for, and is dressed appropriately, that this company would fail to hire her because they refused to accommodate her religious belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, I think it was a store manager.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: She did not mention the headscarf?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Show me where in the script.  Because I remember reading this, and she, in fact, said we don't discuss the Look Policy at the interview.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Okay, but there was no mention of a headscarf in what she read.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So let's say that somebody comes in for an interview and this person is -- has the look, if you wanted to, you know, draw the person who has the look, this is the person who has the look, looks just like this mythical preppy or -- (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- somebody who came off the beach in California.  Only one problem, the person is wearing a black blouse, which is against the Abercrombie rules.  Now, would Abercrombie fire that -- or would not hire that person on the assumption that this person likes black so much this person is going to wear black every single day?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Or a yarmulke.  He said specifically, somebody come in, applies for a job, wears a yarmulke , no questions asked, that violates our policy. Alderson Reporting Company That was his testimony.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, but that doesn't work in a case like this.  It's not a question, are you treating everybody the same.  You have an obligation to accommodate people with particular religious practice or beliefs, so to keep constantly saying, oh, we would have treated somebody with a baseball cap the same way doesn't seem to me is very responsive.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, no, but as I understand it, it's intentional discrimination because you failed to accommodate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Again, how we get into all that, if you want to add something to it, it seems we're in a kind of minutia.  What's wrong with saying if he Alderson Reporting Company correctly believes that she's religious and needs accommodation, fine, that's the end of it.  You're in the statute and prove an excuse.  Correct belief can arise in a thousand contexts.  Did he correctly believe that the drug that was being sold, that white powder, was heroin?  Did the manager whom you're trying to fire and is saying you did, did he correctly believe that, in fact -- or didn't pay enough for college graduates?  Did he correctly believe that this applicant graduated from Princeton?  Did he -- that's Abercrombie -- did he correctly believe that -- that he had authority under the -- under the delegation of agency, to sign a check? I mean, look, there are thousands of things. What's -- why is it our job here to say what the right way of proving correct belief is?  I mean, I think, we can say it's something wrong.  You don't have to formulate your correct belief just because she told you. I mean, you can argue that one.  That's the only way to prove it and I'm open to that argument, I'd like to hear it. But once we're beyond that, if I'm right that that isn't the only way you can prove correct belief, why do we have to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm with you with "suspect."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm with you only where they correctly believe that, dah, dah, dah, or understand dah, dah, dah, or no.  Those three things seem good enough to me. Now, I've repeated this three times, but I want to hear the answer why they're not good enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, isn't that -- isn't that what Ms. Cooke says she did?  She said she saw her in a scarf and that she assumed that it was worn because of religious beliefs, so she acted on a stereotype that some, I guess, if you wear a black Alderson Reporting Company scarf, it's because of a religious belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, he hired her because -- didn't hire her because, under the Look Policy, he believed you could not accommodate that religious belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Or that religious practice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  So -- so the traceable -- now you've got me sort of interested in this -- it seems to me, when you mean traceable to the woman, I mean, you mean it loosely, I guess.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's pretty hard to think of a case where it wouldn't be.  I mean, I guess I could imagine a case that he found out about this woman from an FBI agent who was making it up.  But, I mean, that just seems very, very unlikely. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the applicant's reference didn't know the applicant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: traceable to the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's the difference in your -- I mean, I'm a little -- I'm still very confused. You don't think that there could ever be discrimination based on a general neutral policy, because what does it matter if she told him that this was because of religious belief?  If he's only firing her or not hiring her because of the Look Policy, then he hasn't discriminated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I am so totally confused.  So he hears it from Ms. Cooke and that's not enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We've already gone through this.  All I have to do is say, This is what our Look Policy is, do you have any problem with it?  As Justice Alito pointed out a while back, don't have to probe anything about religion.  I thought Ms. -- what is his name, Johnson -- when he said, I would do the same thing with a man who came in with a yarmulke .  So the man who came in with the yarmulke   got the same treatment. Sorry, I was, I was -- Ms. Cooke, I would want to hire you, but I can't.  That was the answer that he gave.  So there's no difference between the headscarf or yarmulke or a Sikh turban in Mr. Johnson's view.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If it's going to be a requirement for the job, then doesn't the employer have an obligation to tell the employee what the job requirements are?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: This is what I don't understand about your position with respect to this particular case.  As I understand it, Abercrombie does not have a policy that the -- that an interviewee must comply with the Look Policy; is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So what -- on -- there would be no reason for not hiring the individual involved here unless you assumed that she was going to wear a scarf Alderson Reporting Company every day.  Just because she wore a headscarf on that one day, wouldn't mean that she necessarily was going to wear it everyday.  Every day she might.  Maybe she's just having a bad hair day so she comes in with a headscarf, but she doesn't have any religious reason for doing it.  Would you reject her for that?  No.  The reason that she was rejected was because you assumed she was going to do this every day and the only reason why she would do it every day is because she had a religious reason.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why would they ask anything about nonreligious?  Title VII doesn't require accommodating baseball caps, but it does require accommodating to religious practices.  So the employer is not -- as I said before, it's not just, I can't Alderson Reporting Company discriminate on the basis of religion, but if there's a religious practice, I must accommodate it as a discrete requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So why would that be so when you just said they don't require people at the interview stage to conform to the Look Policy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You were about to tell us what the EEOC's theory of the case was.  I was eager to hear that.  Could you tell us what you think their theory of the case was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what's the difference between that and having no --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand what you were about to say.  Would you finish your thought?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But you're essentially saying that the problem with the rule is that it requires Abercrombie to engage in what might be thought of as an awkward conversation, to ask some questions. Now, people can disagree about whether one can ask those questions in a way that's awkward at all, but you're saying we should structure the whole legal system to make sure that there is no possibility of that awkward conversation ever taking place.  But the alternative to that rule is a rule where Abercrombie just gets to say, we're going to stereotype people and prevent them from getting jobs.  We'll never have the awkward conversation because we're just going to cut these people out and make sure that they never become Abercrombie employees. Now, between those two options, the option of using a stereotype to make sure that somebody never gets a job and using a stereotype to have an awkward conversation, which does this statute seem to think is the worst problem? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: They -- Title VII requires them to treat people who have religious practice differently.  They don't have to accommodate a baseball cap.  They do have to accommodate a yarmulke.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  I got you.  Is this right?  I've got, I think, your argument.  Your argument is it may sound odd to want a special rule as to when you have belief or so forth, but for administrative reasons, we have to have it.  There are millions of people who are practicing one religion or another where you get a clue of that from their name or maybe their dress or whatever it is.  And whenever we have such a Alderson Reporting Company person applying, if she doesn't say anything or he doesn't say anything, and we don't hire them or we don't do it, we're going to get sued.  And we don't want all those lawsuits.  And it isn't that big a burden to say to the person who wants the accommodation, tell us. We get into some administrative rule about how to elicit it from her without that simple rule, tell us, we're going to be in a real administrative rat mess getting sued left right and center.  Have I got the essence of your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that isn't the end of the world, perhaps.  But you would say, look, we -- we have thousands of managers and -- and goodness knows they're going to get -- start getting resentful and dah, dah, dah, dah.  I mean, I just want to be sure I've got the argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Frankly, this is such an unusual case because it's very rare that you have an interviewer like Ms. Cooke who's honest.  And the only reason there was a suit here was because she was honest and came in and told someone else.  But if this young -- this young woman wasn't about to sue until she heard this information.  Most people don't presume they're not hired because of some religious practice.  But if you have a policy that conflicts with your religious practice, and the person knows you're going to wear a yarmulke, then you might get sued.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Gershengorn, you have five minutes left. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you want to say a word about what I called his administrative argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't prevent a lawsuit, of course.  I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: She can sue and then find out in the -- in the course of discovery, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it happens often, doesn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
